modules.name: Text.Parsing.Indent
modules.comments:
This is purescript-port of Text.Parsing.Indent
<https://hackage.haskell.org/package/indents-0.3.3/docs/Text-Parsec-Indent.html>, 05.07.2016.
A module to construct indentation aware parsers. Many programming
language have indentation based syntax rules e.g. python and Haskell.
This module exports combinators to create such parsers.

The input source can be thought of as a list of tokens. Abstractly
each token occurs at a line and a column and has a width. The column
number of a token measures is indentation. If t1 and t2 are two tokens
then we say that indentation of t1 is more than t2 if the column
number of occurrence of t1 is greater than that of t2.

Currently this module supports two kind of indentation based syntactic
structures which we now describe:

- **Block**

  A block of indentation /c/ is a sequence of tokens with
  indentation at least /c/.  Examples for a block is a where clause of
  Haskell with no explicit braces.

- **Line fold**

  A line fold starting at line /l/ and indentation /c/ is a
  sequence of tokens that start at line /l/ and possibly continue to
  subsequent lines as long as the indentation is greater than /c/. Such
  a sequence of lines need to be /folded/ to a single line. An example
  is MIME headers. Line folding based binding separation is used in
  Haskell as well.

declarations.comments:
Indentation sensitive parser type. Usually @ m @ will
be @ Identity @ as with any @ ParserT @
declarations.title: IndentParser

declarations.comments: Run the result of an indentation sensitive parse
declarations.title: runIndent

declarations.comments:
`withBlock f a p` parses `a`
followed by an indented block of `p`
combining them with `f`.
declarations.title: withBlock

declarations.comments: Like 'withBlock', but throws away initial parse result
declarations.title: withBlock'

declarations.comments: Parses a block of lines at the same indentation level , empty Blocks allowed
declarations.title: block

declarations.comments: Parses a block of lines at the same indentation level
declarations.title: block1

declarations.comments: Parses only when indented past the level of the reference
declarations.title: indented

declarations.comments: Same as `indented`, but does not change internal state
declarations.title: indented'

declarations.comments: Parses only on the same line as the reference
declarations.title: sameLine

declarations.comments: Parses only when indented past the level of the reference or on the same line
declarations.title: sameOrIndented

declarations.comments: Ensures the current indentation level matches that of the reference
declarations.title: checkIndent

declarations.comments: Parses using the current location for indentation reference
declarations.title: withPos

declarations.comments: `<+/>` is to indentation sensitive parsers what `ap` is to monads
declarations.title: indentAp

declarations.comments: Like `<+/>` but doesn't apply the function to the parsed value
declarations.title: indentNoAp

declarations.comments: Like `<+/>` but applies the second parser many times
declarations.title: indentMany

declarations.comments: Like `<+/>` but applies the second parser optionally using the `Optional` datatype
declarations.title: indentOp

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding brackets
declarations.title: indentBrackets

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding angle brackets
declarations.title: indentAngles

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding braces
declarations.title: indentBraces

declarations.comments: Parses with surrounding parentheses
declarations.title: indentParens

declarations.comments: Data type used to optional parsing
declarations.title: Optional

declarations.comments: A parsing error, consisting of a message and position information.
declarations.title: ParseError

declarations.comments: Contains the remaining input and current position.
declarations.title: ParseState

declarations.comments:
The Parser monad transformer.

The first type argument is the stream type. Typically, this is either `String`,
or some sort of token stream.
declarations.title: ParserT

declarations.comments: The `Parser` monad is a synonym for the parser monad transformer applied to the `Identity` monad.
declarations.title: Parser

declarations.comments: Apply a parser, keeping only the parsed result.
declarations.title: runParser

declarations.comments: Apply a parser, keeping only the parsed result.
declarations.title: runParserT

declarations.comments: Change the underlying monad action and data type in a ParserT monad action.
declarations.title: mapParserT

declarations.comments: Set the consumed flag.
declarations.title: consume

declarations.comments: Returns the current position in the stream.
declarations.title: position

declarations.comments: Fail with a message.
declarations.title: fail

declarations.comments: Fail with a message and a position.
declarations.title: failWithPosition

declarations.comments:
Contextualize parsing failures inside a region. If a parsing failure
occurs, then the `ParseError` will be transformed by each containing
`region` as the parser backs out the call stack.
declarations.title: region

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.Combinators
modules.comments:
Combinators for creating parsers.

### Notes

A few of the known combinators from Parsec are missing in this module. That
is because they have already been defined in other libraries.

```purescript
Text.Parsec.many  = Data.(Array|List).many
Text.Parsec.(<|>) = Control.Alt.alt (<|>)
```

Because Strings are not Char Arrays in PureScript `many` and `some` on Char Parsers need to
be used in conjunction with `Data.String.CodeUnits.fromCharArray` to achieve "Parsec-like" results.

```purescript
Text.Parsec.many  (char 'x') <=> fromCharArray <$> Data.Array.many (char 'x')
```

Note that `Data.(Array|List).(many|some)` are not stack safe. If you need to parse
large numbers of items then consider using `Data.List.(manyRec|someRec)` instead.

declarations.comments: Provide an error message in the case of failure.
declarations.title: withErrorMessage

declarations.comments: Flipped `(<?>)`.
declarations.title: asErrorMessage

declarations.comments:
Wrap a parser with opening and closing markers.

For example:

```purescript
parens = between (string "(") (string ")")
```
declarations.title: between

declarations.comments: Provide a default result in the case where a parser fails without consuming input.
declarations.title: option

declarations.comments: Optionally parse something, failing quietly.
declarations.title: optional

declarations.comments: pure `Nothing` in the case where a parser fails without consuming input.
declarations.title: optionMaybe

declarations.comments: In case of failure, reset the stream to the unconsumed state.
declarations.title: try

declarations.comments: Like `try`, but will reannotate the error location to the `try` point.
declarations.title: tryRethrow

declarations.comments: Parse a phrase, without modifying the consumed state or stream position.
declarations.title: lookAhead

declarations.comments: Match one or more times.
declarations.title: many1

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a separator.

For example:

```purescript
digit `sepBy` string ","
```
declarations.title: sepBy

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a separator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: sepBy1

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and optionally terminated by a separator.
declarations.title: sepEndBy

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and optionally terminated by a separator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: sepEndBy1

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and terminated by a separator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: endBy1

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited and terminated by a separator.
declarations.title: endBy

declarations.comments:
Parse phrases delimited by a right-associative operator.

For example:

```purescript
chainr digit (string "+" *> add) 0
```
declarations.title: chainr

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a left-associative operator.
declarations.title: chainl

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a left-associative operator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: chainl1

declarations.comments: Parse phrases delimited by a right-associative operator, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: chainr1

declarations.comments: Parse one of a set of alternatives.
declarations.title: choice

declarations.comments: Skip many instances of a phrase.
declarations.title: skipMany

declarations.comments: Skip at least one instance of a phrase.
declarations.title: skipMany1

declarations.comments: Fail if the specified parser matches.
declarations.title: notFollowedBy

declarations.comments: Parse several phrases until the specified terminator matches.
declarations.title: manyTill

declarations.comments: Parse several phrases until the specified terminator matches, requiring at least one match.
declarations.title: many1Till

declarations.comments:
Build a parser from an `OperatorTable`.

For example:

```purescript
buildExprParser [ [ Infix (string "/" $> div) AssocRight ]
                , [ Infix (string "*" $> mul) AssocRight ]
                , [ Infix (string "-" $> sub) AssocRight ]
                , [ Infix (string "+" $> add) AssocRight ]
                ] digit
```
declarations.title: buildExprParser

declarations.comments: The language definition for the Haskell language.
declarations.title: haskellDef

declarations.comments: A lexer for the haskell language.
declarations.title: haskell

declarations.comments:
This is the most minimal token definition. It is recommended to use
this definition as the basis for other definitions. `emptyDef` has
no reserved names or operators, is case sensitive and doesn't accept
comments, identifiers or operators.
declarations.title: emptyDef

declarations.comments:
This is a minimal token definition for Haskell style languages. It
defines the style of comments, valid identifiers and case
sensitivity. It does not define any reserved words or operators.
declarations.title: haskellStyle

declarations.comments:
This is a minimal token definition for Java style languages. It
defines the style of comments, valid identifiers and case
sensitivity. It does not define any reserved words or operators.
declarations.title: javaStyle

declarations.comments:
`Position` represents the position of the parser in the input.

- `line` is the current line in the input
- `column` is the column of the next character in the current line that will be parsed
declarations.title: Position

declarations.comments: The `Position` before any input has been parsed.
declarations.title: initialPos

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.String
modules.comments:
Primitive parsers for working with an input stream of type `String`.

The behavior of these primitive parsers is based on the behavior of the
`Data.String` module in the __strings__ package.
In most JavaScript runtime environments, the `String`
is little-endian [UTF-16](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-16).

The primitive parsers which return `Char` will only succeed when the character
being parsed is a code point in the
[Basic Multilingual Plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plane_(Unicode)#Basic_Multilingual_Plane)
(the BMP). These parsers can be convenient because of the good support
that PureScript has for writing `Char` literals like `''`, `''`, `'C'`.

The other primitive parsers, which return `CodePoint` and `String` types,
can parse the full Unicode character set. All of the primitive parsers
in this module can be used together.

declarations.comments: Match the specified string.
declarations.title: string

declarations.comments: Match end-of-file.
declarations.title: eof

declarations.comments:
Match any BMP `Char`.
Parser will fail if the character is not in the Basic Multilingual Plane.
declarations.title: anyChar

declarations.comments:
Match any Unicode character.
Always succeeds.
declarations.title: anyCodePoint

declarations.comments: Match a BMP `Char` satisfying the predicate.
declarations.title: satisfy

declarations.comments: Match a Unicode character satisfying the predicate.
declarations.title: satisfyCodePoint

declarations.comments: Match the specified BMP `Char`.
declarations.title: char

declarations.comments:
Match zero or more whitespace characters satisfying
`Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isSpace`.
declarations.title: whiteSpace

declarations.comments: Skip whitespace characters.
declarations.title: skipSpaces

declarations.comments: Match one of the BMP `Char`s in the array.
declarations.title: oneOf

declarations.comments: Match any BMP `Char` not in the array.
declarations.title: noneOf

declarations.comments:
Combinator which returns both the result of a parse and the portion of
the input that was consumed while it was being parsed.
declarations.title: match

modules.name: Text.Parsing.Parser.Token
modules.comments: Functions for working with streams of tokens.

declarations.comments: Create a parser which Returns the first token in the stream.
declarations.title: token

declarations.comments: Create a parser which matches any token satisfying the predicate.
declarations.title: when

declarations.comments: Match the specified token at the head of the stream.
declarations.title: match

declarations.comments:
The `GenLanguageDef` type is a record that contains all parameterizable
features of the "Text.Parsec.Token" module. The module `Text.Parsec.Language`
contains some default definitions.
declarations.title: GenLanguageDef

declarations.comments:
The type of the record that holds lexical parsers that work on
`s` streams over a monad `m`.
declarations.title: GenTokenParser

declarations.comments:
The expression `makeTokenParser language` creates a `GenTokenParser`
record that contains lexical parsers that are
defined using the definitions in the `language` record.

The use of this function is quite stylized - one imports the
appropiate language definition and selects the lexical parsers that
are needed from the resulting `GenTokenParser`.

```purescript
module Main where

import Text.Parsing.Parser.Language (haskellDef)
import Text.Parsing.Parser.Token (makeTokenParser)

-- The parser
expr = parens expr
   <|> identifier
   <|> ...


-- The lexer
tokenParser = makeTokenParser haskellDef
parens      = tokenParser.parens
braces      = tokenParser.braces
identifier  = tokenParser.identifier
reserved    = tokenParser.reserved
...
```
declarations.title: makeTokenParser

declarations.comments: Parse a digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isDecDigit`.
declarations.title: digit

declarations.comments: Parse a hex digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isHexDigit`.
declarations.title: hexDigit

declarations.comments: Parse an octal digit.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isOctDigit`.
declarations.title: octDigit

declarations.comments: Parse an uppercase letter.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isUpper`.
declarations.title: upper

declarations.comments: Parse a space character.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isSpace`.
declarations.title: space

declarations.comments: Parse an alphabetical character.  Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isAlpha`.
declarations.title: letter

declarations.comments:
Parse an alphabetical or numerical character.
Matches any char that satisfies `Data.CodePoint.Unicode.isAlphaNum`.
declarations.title: alphaNum
